text: [Music]
hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum that i know
you've been asking about blind baking
does your pie shell your Thanksgiving
pie does it turn out like this where the
crust is shrunken and misshapen well
today I'm gonna show you how to blind
bake it so that it doesn't shrink down
on you and you will end up with the most
beautiful pie
this Thanksgiving so I'm gonna start
with a food processor two and a half
cups of all-purpose flour and to that
I'm gonna add one teaspoon of kosher
salt a teaspoon of granulated sugar and
I'm going to pulse this together so that
the salt and the sugar evenly dispersed
with the all-purpose flour now to this
I'm going to add two sticks of unsalted
butter and it's very very cold do you
want to make sure that you cube up your
butter into nice small pieces like this
I think they're about a half-inch cube
and put it into the refrigerator even
the freezer so it's really well chilled
pulse this together until the mixture
resembles a coarse meal with pea-sized
clumps of butter in the flour because
what that does is it melts down in the
dough when you're baking it creating
steam and steam creates these little
pockets which end up creating a flaky
pie crust now to this I'm going to add
ice water anywhere from a quarter of a
cup to a half of a cup I don't like to
pour the water down the feed tube
because I feel like the water builds up
around the blade of a food processor so
I actually like to pour around the side
of the bowl and then quickly pulse this
together a few more times and what
you're looking for here is for the flour
mixture to hold together when you
squeeze it
this is crumbling up in my hand so I
know that I need to add a little bit
more water so I'm going to add the rest
of the 1/2 cup water and pulse it
together a few more times
let's see here gives a mixture a little
bit of a squeeze and you can see that
it's holding together now this isn't a
wet tacky dough and you want to make
sure that it isn't because if you add
too much water to the dough it does
contribute to the shrinkage of the dough
so now I'm going to shape the dough into
disks and I have a piece of plastic wrap
here and I'm going to eyeball out about
half of this mixture and what you want
to do here is you want to take the
plastic wrap use it to your advantage
and compress the dough into one mass you
can see it's still a little crumbly
around the edges but I'm going to show
you how to fix that because any crumbly
bits around the edge of your disc of
dough in the end when you go to roll it
out is going to crack around the edges
which isn't great Pat the dough out in
the plastic wrap and then take your
rolling pin here and then actually roll
the dough gently into the plastic wrap
and what that does is it compresses the
dough into one cohesive disc if you have
one of these this is a plastic bench
scraper or you could use a regular bench
scraper you could use a ruler anything
with a straight side and give the dough
a nice rounded shape so there you go a
perfectly round disc of pie dough I'm
going to repeat the process with the
remaining dough and this will give you
enough for two single crust pies or one
double crust pie but into the
refrigerator for at least an hour until
it's really well chilled I have my pie
dough it's been chilling for at least an
hour and it's been out about five
minutes because you don't want to roll
it when it's completely cold otherwise
it will crack on you and on a lightly
floured surface just gonna sprinkle the
top lightly with some flour as well and
your rolling pin make sure you use a
decent amount of flour you don't want to
add too much because you're gonna work
flour into your dough which will toughen
your dough in one fluid motion that's
how you want a roll dough you want to
roll away from you and then constantly
rotate your pie dough and this is really
important you have to keep it moving
otherwise it will start to stick and I'm
gonna roll this out into a 13 inch
diameter and that's
for a nine inch a classic 9 inch pie
plate and now I'm ready to fit it into
the pie plate so use your rolling pin
here to help you out a little bit you
can use your bench scraper and just roll
the dough up onto the rolling pin it's
the easiest way to get it into the pie
plate and use a pastry brush like this a
nice wide pastry brush to get off any
excess flour so now put your pie plate
directly in front of your dough and all
you have to do simply is unravel the
dough and it fits right into the pie
plate now gently push the dough into any
of the corners trim the edges of the
dough here leaving a half inch border
and that will be enough to roll the
crust underneath the pie shell simply
like this creating a nice edge for me to
crimp and now for a very simple crimped
edge use your thumb your pointer finger
and your other thumb and gently press
the dough into a nice simple crimped
edge it goes into the refrigerator now
to chill or you can even put it into the
freezer for at least 15 to 20 minutes
until it's nice and solid so our
beautiful pie shell has been in the
freezer for about 15 minutes it's really
well chilled and now for the blind
baking process and what is blind baking
well simply it's pre baking the pie
shell so that it's ready for custard
fillings for pumpkin pie filling for any
of those wonderful coconut cream pies
I'm gonna take a piece of parchment
paper and I'm going to sprinkle it up
and what this does is it helps to make
the parchment paper a little bit more
malleable so that it fits nicely into
the pie plate and now for the weights I
like to use lentils or split peas
anything that's small that will really
fit into all of the nooks and crannies
of the pie shell and help to prevent it
from bubbling up this goes into a
preheated 375 degree oven for about 30
minutes and you want to make sure in
check that the bottom of the crust is
completely set before removing
beam's so I'm gonna go right into the
oven it's been 30 minutes in the oven
the crust looks nice and set and I'm
going to remove the pie weights now the
parchment and the pilot lift out the
parchment parcel here and you can see
the bottom crust is not soggy it's not
wet it's pretty much dry but it needs to
brown up in the oven so it's gonna back
into the oven for about five minutes
more so it's been about five to ten
minutes more and the bottom crust is
nice and brown and it's beautifully
plate you can tell and now we're ready
for our pumpkin pie filling our coconut
cream filling or whatever filling you
have in mind for this Thanksgiving so
there you have it blind baking kitchen
conundrum solved
[Music]
